awd_titl_txt: QLCI-CG: Center for Interdisciplinary Research in Quantum Information Theory and Simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
The Quantum Leap Challenge Institutes (QLCI) program is part of the Quantum Leap, one of the research Big Ideas promoted by the National Science Foundation. This award is a QLCI Conceptualization Grant, which supports activities to build capacity among teams planning for the large-scale, interdisciplinary Challenge Institute projects that aim to advance the frontiers of quantum information science and engineering. Research at these Institutes will span the focus areas of quantum computation, quantum communication, quantum simulation, and/or quantum sensing. The Institutes are expected to foster multidisciplinary approaches to specific scientific, technological, and workforce development goals in these fields. 

This Conceptualization Grant will develop well-formulated plans for a future Challenge Institute proposal that seeks to fill the theory gap between existing quantum information science theory and real-world experimental platforms for quantum computing, simulation, and communication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to assist team formation and to strategize for a NSF-QLCI proposal submission. The funds supported three separate workshops in 2019, 2022, and 2023. All three workshops took place at the Virginia Tech Arlington Research Center in Arlington, Virginia.

 

In 2019, the PIs, in collaboration with PIs from a second NSF QLCI Conceptualization Grant led the University of Washington, Seattle, organized and hosted a workshop on Quantum Information Science and Engineering (QISE) training and workforce development, with participation from (i) the major US and European universities that have started (or are developing) quantum programs, (ii) major QISE industry (IBM, Google, Microsoft, etc), (iii) QISE startups (Zapata, PsiQuantum, QCWare, etc), (iv) national labs (Sandia, NIST, LPS), and (v) QED-C. This was a two-day event. The participants identified and discussed the challenges associated with developing QISE graduate degrees in the US, and received input from potential future employers (industry, national labs).

 

In addition to the 2019 workshop, which was intended to help our team prepare the workforce development component of our QLCI proposal, the PIs also participated in multiple meetings with the 30+ senior personnel involved in our QLCI proposal, where new projects and collaborations were formed. These meetings took place over Zoom due to the pandemic, and so the project funds were not utilized as initially anticipated. Multiple project ideas and research directions were developed. These QLCI planning meetings also helped conceptualize the formation of a new QISE summer school. Virginia Tech launched this summer school (virtually) for the first time in July 2021, and it has been held every summer ever since.

 

In 2022, this project supported another workshop, this time organized by junior researchers from the PIs’ groups. The workshop brought together junior theorists and junior experimentalists from the QISE community. Senior researchers also participated, but the talks were exclusively given by postdocs and PhD students. There were participants from Virginia Tech, University of Maryland Baltimore County, Johns Hopkins University, Applied Physics Lab, and the University of Rochester. During the pandemic, there were a lot of online conferences and workshops. However, these focused mostly on senior researchers, leaving junior researchers with fewer opportunities to present their work and to network with the community. Our goal was to instead support junior researcher-focused workshops to help accelerate their professional development, which was especially important coming out of the pandemic. The event brought together people who would not normally interact, and new research collaborations were initiated as a consequence of the workshop.

 

In 2023, the remaining QLCI-CG funds were used to support a second junior researcher-focused workshop. Postdocs and PhD students from Virginia Tech organized a workshop in QISE for early-career researchers. The workshop brought together senior PhD students, postdocs, and assistant professors from various related disciplines and from both theory and experiment. The organizers and participants had thus the opportunity to broaden their professional network within the large field of QISE. The organizers also gained experience in workshop organization.
